item.title: Remarkably stable politics is among the reasons why Uruguay has done so well https://t.co/Q8ZbE5jcB9

“If there is anything in Russia you can be proud of right now, it is those people who have been detained,” Alexei Navalny, Russia’s jailed opposition leader, wrote in a statement https://t.co/WMOZuPHoVX
No major economy in the modern world has ever been hit so hard by sanctions https://t.co/vDK0G2Tjtc

“Western politicians danced with Vladimir Putin (some of them literally) and retired to chair the boards of Russian companies,” writes Ingrida Simonyte. “These firms funded the Kremlin’s arms race and diverted billions to Mr Putin’s entourage” https://t.co/4uJ2jnqR7W
More than the people of any other country in Asia, people in Taiwan are stirred by the plight of Ukraine https://t.co/lnRdkZkMGm
Emmanuel Macron has confirmed he will run for re-election. Our forecast suggests he has an 88% chance of winning https://t.co/QI0R4jMYCP
Our French election forecasting model puts Emmanuel Macron’s chances of re-election at 88% https://t.co/14SMEwBM4u

From the start, Vladimir Putin has made clear that this is a war of escalation. He threatens to be more destructive even if that means resorting to a nuclear weapon. The world must stand up to him. Our cover this week https://t.co/RuaETMqc9z https://t.co/2uzypdsMy2
Some instances of violence in Ukraine that might meet the criteria have been captured on phones https://t.co/7vLsbxPK0p

After invading Ukraine nearly a week ago, Vladimir Putin has ordered Russia’s nuclear forces to be on high alert.
What might he do next, and how should NATO respond? @shashj, The Economist’s defence editor, gives his take.
Read our latest analysis: https://t.co/Ku48sueqh2 https://t.co/CjMMsgokGw
In a country fast turning totalitarian, there is plenty of room for bravery. More than 1m people in Russia have signed a petition against the war https://t.co/x17mWaaHzl

The world must be willing to bleed Vladimir Putin’s regime of the resources that enable him to wage war and abuse his own people even if that imposes costs on Western economies https://t.co/orDctaCFLo

One goal of Russia’s advance in Ukraine is to create a “land bridge” that connects the Russian-speaking Donbas, and Russia itself, with Crimea, which it annexed in 2014.
To achieve its aims, Russia will need to hold its new turf. Can it do that?
Russia rejects the jurisdiction of the ICC. But there is no serious doubt that Russia has broken international law https://t.co/jWU6Ymbtwr
It took more than 30 years for BP, a British energy company, to build its Russian business. It took less than four days to decide to dismantle it https://t.co/703tCyk1QH

The idea that Vladimir Putin would carry out his threat to use battlefield nuclear weapon is surely unlikely. Unfortunately, it is not impossible: he has just invaded his neighbour https://t.co/LGCtztiJGY
“The crisis is not in Ukraine,” writes @IngridaSimonyte. “It is in Russia, and it has been deepening for decades. Russia’s aggression began long ago” https://t.co/VbljNzyj5E

“They are ready to fight.” Our correspondent reports with the latest from Kyiv.
Click to watch ⬇️
He insists that the world back off while he sharpens his knife and sets about his slaughter. Other countries must stand up to him https://t.co/HB15yMbp6u
Videos of cluster bombs in Kharkiv and even an attack on a kindergarten in Okhtyrka offer evidence of indiscriminate attacks on civilians https://t.co/5kIx7gRX9w
Is Vladimir Putin a war criminal? And if so, is it possible to charge him? A thread 👇 https://t.co/9cHiSCusFX https://t.co/FvBfgozUzy
Thirty-nine governments—a record number—appealed to the ICC to open an investigation into possible war crimes committed by Russia in Ukraine https://t.co/nwGnEdHRcJ

“If it escalates…it could be the biggest war in Europe since the second world war with all of the consequences you’d expect.” @shashj on how Vladimir Putin’s attacks on Ukraine could escalate https://t.co/KF5Mu8IRko

From the start, he has made clear that this is a war of escalation. He threatens to be more destructive even if that means resorting to a nuclear weapon. The world must stand up to him https://t.co/zWe925mRvP
If he prevails in Ukraine today, his next fix will be in Georgia, Moldova or the Baltic states. He will not stop until he is stopped. The world must stand up to him https://t.co/ZCNhu45Dd4

The West’s measures have triggered chaos in Russia’s $1.6trn economy. This will cause alarm around the world, not least in China, which will recalculate the costs of a war over Taiwan https://t.co/mMCU8gmcEi

I can’t tell you what is happening where there is fighting but my local supermarket has reopened after being closed for a week. Only a small queue. Importantly it has had deliveries including bread and milk! #Kyiv #Ukraine https://t.co/sXirFoA1HH

From the start, Vladimir Putin has made clear that this is a war of escalation. He threatens to be more destructive even if that means resorting to a nuclear weapon. The world must stand up to him. Our cover this week https://t.co/iWvQNzeN4u https://t.co/gMiFJrNbmV
As Russian troops advance towards Kyiv, Ukrainian forces are preparing to fight back. Our correspondent reports with the latest from Kyiv https://t.co/3QqI3ayO3I https://t.co/es9s9JN9Rz
The West has used crushing sanctions on Russia. The implications are huge https://t.co/y6TfUvWehU
A world run by big countries appeals to Chinese nationalists, who have filled social media with praise for Vladimir Putin https://t.co/yKveGSoN9Q
Russia’s economy is clearly in turmoil. Vladimir Putin’s actions in Ukraine might end up choking his own citizens https://t.co/Yka3G9wK0u
Before the war Ukrainian teenagers liked to text each other photos of Russian rappers. Now the image circulating on their phones is of the so-called “ghost of Kyiv” https://t.co/3nxZkziAr0
Vladimir Putin’s unprovoked invasion of a sovereign state has shocked some European countries into breaking old pacifist taboos https://t.co/e4fogx8wXO

When Vladimir Putin invaded Ukraine he miscalculated. Now that he is wielding the threat of nuclear war, the world must make clear that his actions are unacceptable. He must not miscalculate again https://t.co/Knrqg3U8Wn
If Vladimir Putin has to destroy cities like Kyiv and Kharkiv in order to impose a puppet government on Ukraine, he will in an important sense have already lost the war https://t.co/kh8tkyfrAE
Ukraine has spent centuries trying to find a national hero. The past days have produced dozens, writes @akurkov for @1843mag https://t.co/HoVpNWX1Nj
After one week of a war that has killed more than 2,000 Ukrainian civilians, according to the Ukrainian government, Vladimir Putin now has a territorial trophy to show for it https://t.co/KBaQnfJMM4
Since it gained independence in 1991, Ukraine has struggled to find heroes around whom to build a national myth. But the past days have produced dozens https://t.co/bHkRbfS6nX

“Everybody must see now that President Putin will not be stopped with persuasion or sanctions,” writes Ukraine’s former defence minister. “The time has come to take the first really effective step and to impose a no-fly zone” https://t.co/EgEtMw1jqT
Civilians went to bed in a Ukrainian city and woke up in a Russian-controlled one. We report on the fall of Kherson https://t.co/h8rtF0ZQla
The Russian invasion of Ukraine is not going to plan. The president has made three key mistakes https://t.co/xFUI1wa56d

A no-fly zone “will stop Russia from launching devastating missile strikes, dropping bombs or undertaking large-scale air assault operations,” writes Ukraine’s former defence minister in a guest commentary https://t.co/V3oOHJSyGn

“Western politicians danced with Vladimir Putin (some of them literally) and retired to chair the boards of Russian companies,” writes Ingrida Simonyte. “These firms funded the Kremlin’s arms race and diverted billions to Mr Putin’s entourage” https://t.co/p6wwNbOqDc
If they believed President Putin’s goal was a modern economy that he would not jeopardise by invading Ukraine, they were wrong https://t.co/o3qkOFSUoL
Ukraine’s president, Volodymyr Zelensky, has become cooler than St Petersburg grime with his defiant social media videos https://t.co/fSzWWLmfam
A no fly-zone would “essentially mean the US military would be shooting down…Russian planes”, warned the White House https://t.co/wxGGJABSjS
Countries arming Ukraine “cannot fail to understand the degree of danger” they are flirting with, says Russia’s foreign ministry. Suppliers seem undaunted https://t.co/xjcKWIlZ8x
Xi Jinping and his government maintain a pose of pseudo-neutrality towards the conflict in Ukraine, but nobody doubts China’s pro-Russian lean https://t.co/FcVuILsVxH
The prospect of facing legal charges might possibly deter some of Vladimir Putin’s lieutenants from following orders to commit war crimes https://t.co/7LunhvEDM3
